issues.title: No flask inregration?
issues.body: Would be nice to use with existing flask apps that need additional services.

issues.title: Flaky daemonize test
issues.body:
test_daemon.py is failing sporadically on my linux desktop:

```
===================================================================================================== FAILURES ======================================================================================================
___________________________________________________________________________________________ SimpleTestCase.test_daemonize ___________________________________________________________________________________________

self = <tests.test_daemon.SimpleTestCase testMethod=test_daemonize>

    def test_daemonize(self):
        if not HAS_DAEMONIZE:
            raise Skip("need `daemonize` for this test case")

        def daemon_helper():
            time.sleep(100)
            self.fail()

        with NamedTemporaryFile() as tf:
            # Fork so daemonizing the current process does not mess up with the
            # test suite.
            child_pid = os.fork()
            if child_pid == 0:
                try:
                    daemon.daemonize(daemon_helper, name='sparts_unittest',
                                     pidfile=tf.name, logger=self.logger)
                except SystemExit:
                    # Catch the daemonize library's attempt to sys.exit()
                    pass
            else:

                def checkdaemon():
                    try:
                        return daemon.status(tf.name, self.logger)
                    except ValueError:
                        return False

                # Eliminate the race condition waiting for
                # daemonize.Daemonize() to create *and* write the pid to the
                # pidfile.
                timer.run_until_true(checkdaemon, timeout=1.0)

                self.assertTrue(daemon.status(tf.name, self.logger))
>               self.assertTrue(daemon.kill(tf.name, self.logger))

tests/test_daemon.py:92: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
/usr/lib/python2.7/tempfile.py:427: in __exit__
    self.close()
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

self = <closed file '<fdopen>', mode 'w+b' at 0x7f03d84dfed0>

    def close(self):
        if not self.close_called:
            self.close_called = True
            self.file.close()
            if self.delete:
>               self.unlink(self.name)
E               OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/tmp/tmpRNzIO8'

/usr/lib/python2.7/tempfile.py:418: OSError
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Captured stderr call ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
```

issues.title: test_tornado's test_execute_async flaky
issues.body:
It seems this test may be flaky given that it succeeded on all other python flavors.
https://travis-ci.org/facebook/sparts/jobs/119671018

```
tests/tasks/test_settaskoption.py ..
tests/tasks/test_tornado.py .
=================================== FAILURES ===================================
________________________ TestMyTask.test_execute_async _________________________
self = <tests.tasks.test_periodic.TestMyTask testMethod=test_execute_async>
    def test_execute_async(self):
        f = self.task.execute_async()
        res = f.result(3.0)
        self.assertNotNone(res)
        self.assertGreater(res, 0)

        # Verify exception path
        self.task.fail_async = True
        with self.assertRaises(Exception) as ctx:
            # Call this twice, since there's a race condition where setting
            # fail_async and getting the future from execute_async is called
            # when execute is between the self.fail_async check and the return
            self.task.execute_async().result(1.0)
>           self.task.execute_async().result(1.0)
E           AssertionError: Exception not raised
tests/tasks/test_periodic.py:60: AssertionError
```

issues.title: Support persistence in PollerTask
issues.body:
Add a flag that will enable writing fetched values to disk, restore on startup.

add a validate hook to verify the contents in case the format changed.

issues.title: gflags support
issues.body:
It's common to use py wrapped cpp libraries that use gflags.

Build a bridge to expose any gflags defined in this way theough argparse, and preferably the options interfaces as well

issues.title: Support for triggering in-thread execution of `PeriodicTask`
issues.body: Maybe called `trigger()`?

issues.title: Switch from `six` to `python-future`
issues.body: `six` is nice, but `python-future` provides more compatibility (e.g., backports), useful for obsoleting some other modules/dependencies like ordereddict, and futures

issues.title: -W (--warnings) option with default to error
issues.body:
Support a flag like python's -W

Default should be -Werror instead of -Wdefault

issues.title: Thrift usage statistics
issues.body:
fbthrift's python implementation provides `TProcessorEventHandler` hooks; this allows us to monitor thrift server method usage and errors, and potentially even call duration.

Let's figure out how to get this functionality for sparts, either by switching to fbthrift, conditionally using the API (if present), or emulating it with some kind of dynamic TProcessor subclass or wrapper.

issues.title: thrift libraries incompatible with py3k
issues.body:
Currently, sparts' thrift support depends on [apache thrift](https://github.com/apache/thrift), which (to my knowledge) does not generate py3k compatible code.

[fbthrift](github.com/facebook/fbthrift)'s compiler is capable of generating py3k compatible code, but (a) its different command line arguments are incompatible with `sparts.thrift.compiler` and (b) the fbthrift Python bindings are not appropriately packaged (e.g., on pypi)

issues.title: Unittest logspew in tests/tasks/test_tornado.py with python-3.4
issues.body:
Since effectively enabling -Wall in unit test runs, the following logs appear when running: `py.test tests/tasks/test_tornado.py` with python-3.4.0.

```
Exception ignored in: <_io.FileIO name=11 mode='wb'>
ResourceWarning: unclosed file <_io.FileIO name=11 mode='wb'>
Exception ignored in: <_io.FileIO name=10 mode='rb'>
ResourceWarning: unclosed file <_io.FileIO name=10 mode='rb'>
```

This does not repro with python 3.3.5:

issues.title: Automatic man-page generator
issues.body: Provide some hooks to generate a man page file for the configured arguments and docstrings.

issues.title: Enable OSX travis support
issues.body: Might be tricky since we build the thrift compiler from source

issues.title: Rate limit helpers / hooks for QueueTask
Declarative, bindable events
issues.body: We use `threading.Event()`s in a couple of places in code.  Making these `_Bindable` class attributes will allow us to define them declaratively and enable them to be more easily exported.

issues.title: Published documentation
issues.body: As part of the build process, publish documentation.  Possibly to https://pythonhosted.org/ ?

issues.title: Auto-Reconnect support for ThriftClient
issues.body: If we're re-using the client and it gets timed out, let's reconnect automatically.

issues.title: Fb303++
issues.body:
fb303 only provides so much extra value.  A base sparts service can build on top of this:
- clearWarnings, getWarnings
- exportedValues
- getTaskTracebacks
- getMemTypeStats
- getCpuUsage
- remote/local debug hooks

issues.title: Make it easier / better to work with tornado web
issues.body:
Tornado's http object model is fairly verbose.  On top of that, it's not super easy to transparently integrate in a way that results in good monitoring / metrics

Do something about this.

issues.title: CronTask
issues.body: Like PeriodicTask, but supporting cron spec.  Maybe a parent class of Periodic?

issues.title: Thread safe counters
issues.body: Currently they're not really thread safe

issues.title: Infinite windows for samples
issues.body: Add ability for samples to export an "infinite" time window.

issues.title: Thrown TryLater should support a delay/backoff
issues.body:
Right now, TryLater's work or periodic and queue executions by re-running and/or re-inserting the work into the queue instantly.

Support setting an attribute on TryLater() that contains the time to wait in ms before trying again.

issues.title: inotify task
issues.body:
A common use case is watching a directory / tree for changes and acting on changes.

inotify (e.g., pyinotify) is the proper way of handling this.

Create a task for monitoring a filesystem path for changes.

issues.title: Configuration helpers
issues.body:
Support auto-configuration (e.g., of command line arguments' defaults) in a sensible and/or intuitive way.

That is, provide some API for a service to specify that it should have its configuration auto-loaded from some well-defined set of locations.  This should use well-known native or opensource APIs.

The configuration should be in a format that is intuitive to read/set-up but should also be comprehensive.  Ultimately, it should translate to specifying defaults for command line arguments (e.g., sparts "options").

When running with -h, the %(default)s in the helptext should reflect the results of found configuration files.  Additionally there should be some log message or stderr output that indicates what configuration file is being used during startup.

issues.title: scribe integration?
issues.body: Support logging messages directly to scribe.

issues.title: Documentation
issues.body: generate proper pydocs for everything.

commit.message:
Merge pull request #110 from tiagmoraismorgado/patch-1

fixing minor spelling typos
fixing minor spelling typos

Merge pull request #108 from djipko/master

QueuTask: prevent unhandled exception from tearing the main loop down

QueuTask: prevent unhandled exception from tearing the main loop down

Prior to this patch - raising an exception inside an execute() of a
queued
task when using futures instead of deferreds, would tear down the whole
service thread. This is almost certainly not what we want.

The cleanest way to fix this seems to be in the ExecutionContext, where
we consider an exception handled if it's set on a future, and let the
submitter worry about it.

Attempt to fix race in SelectTask

Let's mark the future as running as soon as we create it.  By the time
ProcessStreamHandler() is instantiated, the caller has passed us an
already running Popen, so it doesn't make much sense to create the
adapter before setting this.

This should fix #106 and #99
Officially add 3.5 support
Remove python 3.2 support

Merge pull request #104 from chantra/fix_nargs

[option] handle nargs properly

[travis] Force running in containers, not VM

* Add support for IPv6 loopback
* speed up test spin up

[tests] Fix test_daemon to not abort the rest of the test suite

If we do not fork within the test where we daemonize, the current
process will get daemonize and the test suite will stop.

Enforce Twisted<15.5.0 for python 2.6

15.5.0 is the last release supporting python 2.6 [0]... but actually
doesn't support it [1].
Let's make it <15.5.0
[0] https://twistedmatrix.com/trac/browser/tags/releases/twisted-15.5.0/NEWS?format=raw
[1] https://twistedmatrix.com/trac/browser/tags/releases/twisted-15.5.0/twisted/__init__.py#L16

[option] handle nargs properly

Fixes #103

More thrift.compiler tweaks

- whitespace fix
- use six.iteritems instead of .iteritems() method
- explicitly pass mode='w' when writing to NamedTemporaryFile for importThriftStr

Make compiler.{get|require}_executable public

Some internal functions in thrift.compiler are reusable in unit tests.
Explicitly expose them and use them.
Version bump to 0.7.3
Correctly skip test_multiplexed when thrift bindings not present

Fix bug in file unittest exposed by mock changes

Previously, Mock was returning a mock object on accesses to all
undefined attributes, so when calling `assert_called`, we'd get
back a mock object which is implicitly True.

Newer versions of mock seem to correctly raise an AttributeError,
so we need to use the correct function.
Include TMultiplexedServer, CppServer CHANGES
Add a test case to verify Multiplexed server/client functionality

[thrift] Add more useful error for multiple processors when MULTIPLEX=False

Suggest setting MULTIPLEX = True on your server

TMultiplexed{Service|Protocol} Proof of Concept

Fixes #102
Some comment updates in ThriftServerTask
Initial version of TCppServer-based ThriftServerTask
Prefer thrift1 (fbthrift) compiler when available
Refactor sparts/tasks/thrift.py into submodules
Updated CHANGES.txt for recent changes

ThriftClient should throw during constructor on invalid module

When the compiled thrift module is passed instead of the service module,
throw in the constructor with a helpful error message.
Fix sparts.thrift.compiler convenience compile method

Merge pull request #101 from bboozzoo/bboozzoo/sdist-license

manifest: add manifest

manifest: add manifest

Adding MANIFEST so that both LICENSE and PATENTS will be picked up for
source dist. Although not required this is generally useful when
packaging for Linux distributions.

Signed-off-by: Maciek Borzecki <maciek.borzecki@gmail.com>

I guess I could try to run it on a centos box in EC2 but before I do that could you give me some instruction on how I'd test it? While familiar with thrift rpc I don't know anything about dbus.

I've merged / tweaked most of the commits except for the (last) vfb303 bugfix because I believe I'm (ab)using it in the dbus implementation and casting to str() will eliminate the native types / variant support.

That might be fine, but I should change the method from variant to str.  There might need to be some changes to the corresponding `setOption()` path if I do that though.

I'll take another look at it tomorrow night.

I don't think dbus works well on anything other than Linux
awesome! I don't need the getOption fix any time soon, just needed to hack it for manual testing. should I close this PR?

@fmoo here's what I'm doing in my service:

read some messages off an aws sqs queue (up to 10 at a time) with a PeriodicTask (interval 0). Iterate through them and use a blocking put on my QueueTask's queue. That iteration of adding to the queue will only go as fast as the workers can pull stuff off. If the workers get backed up, I'll have up to 10 messages in memory but won't pick up anymore from sqs till I have capacity to process them. The real choke point is a downstream api call to a system that can get way bogged down.
I cut #65 to fix the getOption thing long term.  I'll close this out.
Looks good!
@fmoo I don't see this commit in master, were u gonna merge?
oops!

Deadlocks (or rather, unexpected blocking) can occur if you set the queue size too low and do a blocking queue.put() in a place where you are not expecting to block.

It's a good way to put backpressure on other tasks, but will require folks to take care is all.
got it (that's exactly what I'm doing with it). I thought you meant something scarier
This is ok with me.

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,4 +1,7 @@
-import unittest2
+try:
+    import unittest2
+except ImportError:

review_comments.body: not too sure how this plays with the stuff in `BaseSpartsTestCase.tearDown` but since you wrote it @fmoo I figured I'd run it by you first. +from sparts.tests.base import MultiTaskTestCase, Skip
+try:
+    import dbus
+    from sparts.tasks.dbus import DBusServiceTask, DBusMainLoopTask
+except ImportError:
+    raise Skip("dbus support is required to run this test")
+
+from sparts.sparts import option
+
+class TestDBusTask(DBusServiceTask):
+    BUS_NAME = 'com.github.facebook.test'
+
+
+class TestDBusSystemTask(DBusServiceTask):
+    BUS_NAME = 'com.github.facebook.systemtest'
+

review_comments.body:
You shouldn't need to specify `name=...` in your option.

EDIT: Is there some issue with overrides not working if you don't specify the name?
In general we prefer to do this with class attributes, e.g., in the parent set `USE_SYSTEM_BUS=False`, then in the parent option, set `default=(lambda cls: cls.USE_SYSTEM_BUS)`

@@ -134,9 +143,21 @@ def initTask(self):
     def mainloop(self):
         return self.mainloop_task.mainloop
 
+    def asyncRun(self, cb, *args):
review_comments.body:
I'm thinking something like this might be cleaner / more easier to reuse:

``` python
def asyncRun(self, cb, *args, **kwargs):

    def _future_execute(f, cb, *args, **kwargs):
        try:
            # Only execute `cb` if the future wasn't cancelled
            if f.set_running_or_notify_cancel():
                f.set_result(cb(*args, **kwargs))
        except Exception as e:
            f.set_exception(e)

    def _future_cancel(f, handle):
        if f.cancelled():
            glib.source_remove(handle)

    f = Future()
    handle = glib.idle_add(partial(_future_execute, f, cb, *args, **kwargs))
    f.add_done_callback(partial(_future_cancel, f, handle))
    return f
```

This seems good because:
- The caller can choose to call `f.result()` on their own,  with or without a timeout as desired
- Callers don't have to implement future semantics in their callbacks or wrapping cb with the try:/except: blocks. 
- It support callers cancelling the idle-added function with native glib apis to remove the event source id as appropriate as well.
- It allows for **kwargs as well as *args since the wrapped callback passed to glib is a partial

Thoughts?

         return self.mainloop_task.mainloop
 
+    def asyncRun(self, cb, *args):
review_comments.body: Fair points. I'll update the code and push patches.

@@ -24,6 +26,11 @@
 import glib
 import time
 
+# always init threads before calling any dbus code
+glib.threads_init()
review_comments.body:
Is there a way to leave this in DBusMainLoopTask?  Dependency resolution should force its' initTask() to execute first before any other tasks' (who might depend on it?) 

Initializing stuff like this in module scope is problematic for a variety of reasons and I'd like to avoid it if possible.

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -24,6 +26,11 @@
 import glib
 import time
 
+# always init threads before calling any dbus code
+glib.threads_init()
review_comments.body:
> Initializing stuff like this in module scope is problematic for a variety of reasons and I'd like to avoid it if possible.

Ok. I guess anyone using the old glib bindings would call threads_init() somewhere at the beginning of the program anyway, so it's fine to move these changes back to where they were originally.

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -201,6 +201,7 @@ def set_exception(self, exception):
         self.timer.stop()
         if self.future is not None:
             self.future.set_exception(exception)
+            handled = True
review_comments.body:
Add a comment above, like:

``` python
# For future-based work, let's allow the submitter to handle the exception
# gracefully.  Since we can't know if that was successful, just assume the
# exception will be handled (or re-raised) by someone awaiting the future.
# This isn't guaranteed, but is a reasonable assumption.
```

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -201,6 +201,7 @@ def set_exception(self, exception):
         self.timer.stop()
         if self.future is not None:
             self.future.set_exception(exception)
+            handled = True
review_comments.body:
Will do - thanks! In case of QueueTask - this decision makes sense since submit() returns a future instance so it's basically a part of it's public API.

Also in QueueTask.map() we rely on the future to throw to the caller as we call result() on it.
